Stu Freeman is correct. Indian restaurants and, in fact, Indians do not call all ice cream "kulfi". Similar to how some people regard gelato to be a different type of ice cream (rather than just the Italian word for ice cream), kulfi is just a frozen dairy dessert (or, if you will, a type of ice cream) that is super dense and stays frozen for a long time. Not to mention it tastes like a frozen stick of butter (in a good way).
Technically most Indian restaurants refer to kulfi as "kulfi" and to ice cream as "ice cream."  Their dessert menus frequently include both.

You do not understand the facts correctly. There were two separate American facilities in Benghazi, located some distance apart. One was a relatively small State Department facility, guarded by a small group of local Libyan guards. The other was a larger and more heavily defended but supposedly undercover CIA facility. The CIA has never disclosed what the nature or purpose of this facility was.

For some reason, the U.S. Ambassador, who was usually based in the U.S. Embassy in Tripoli, chose to visit the small State Department facility in Benghazi. It came attack and was set on fire, and he apparently died in the fire. The CIA dispatched a team of armed CIA agents to go to the State Department facility, rescue as many of the State Department personnel as it could, and return to the more heavily guarded CIA facility. Under attack, they could not find either the Ambassador or his body, and left without him.

After they got back to the CIA facility, it too came under attack. The attackers outnumbered the defenders, and also had medium weapons, including at least one mortar. A mortar round killed two of the CIA personnel, both of them former Navy SEALs, who were defending the facility.

Soon after, a convoy of CIA vehicles left the CIA facility, carrying both State Department and CIA personnel, fought their way through the encirclement of the CIA facility, and escaped to Tripoli.

The "talking points" issue is nonsense. The real issue is why security was so weak.

RIGHT ON, edward smith!  The immigration problem will never be solved with wishy-washy, convoluted euphemisms.  In fact, in my opinion, there is only one way to solve our immigration problem:  eliminate the reasons the "illegals" (or fill in whatever word you prefer)  cross our borders.  Jobs, money, welfare, free medical care, schools.  Prohibit receiving those things and the problem will solve itself.  Otherwise, we and our Congress will have to jury-rig some way to make these 11 million into citizens.  Then 11 million next year. And then 11 million more.  And so on.  And guess who will pay the bills......

...and it might be enlightening to recall the conditions which the newcomers found when they arrived here around the turn of the last century:  there was no OSHA, no sick leave, no 5 day week, no child labor laws, no unemployment compensation, no welfare, no food stamps.  Let's see, what else?  Oh, yes.  The concept of discrimination as we know it did not exist.  It was part of both the social and legal structure at the time: NINA meant at various times, No Irish Need Apply, No Italians Need Apply, No Immigrants Need Apply.  And, oh yes, since this article appears in the NYT, we must once again insist on drawing the essential distinction between legal immigration and unlawful entry into our country.  Sorry, NYT, your rather liberal readership won't let you get away with this obfuscation.  Relatively few are actually "anti-immigrant", and those of us who vigorously oppose condoning unlawful entry refuse to be tarred with the same brush.

I just laugh at Greenhouse's gymnastic gyrations to avoid calling illegal aliens just that.  At one point it's "undocumented immigrant".  Another is "undocumented resident".  Yet another is just plain "immigrants" who should come out of the shadows.  Well why doesn't Greenhouse use the more precise name- "illegal invader".  Because she has an ax to grind in getting legislation to allow all these "illegal invaders" to cut in the front of all the other immigrants who follow the law, wait patiently and have been admitted legally to the country.  Because she does not respect the laws that my grandparents and probably hers followed in entering this country.  We hear the stories of children born here to invader parents who would be separated if the parents were deported to whence they came and the children who came as infants but know no other country.  Greenhouse, I suspect, supports the proposed legislation which opens the legalization process to those who came as recently as 2012 and which many advocates support making the breakpoint of as of April 2013.  I am old enough to remember the promises of the immigration control accompanying the path to citizenship for illegals in the 1980s.  I will not be fooled twice.

In another couple of weeks, it'll be Memorial Day. Places that have out-of-control wildfires will have wildfires. Places that have tornadoes will have tornadoes. Temperatures will rise and we'll hear about record highs and hear worries about corn crops. (Knee high by fourth of July.)

Fourth of July will come. We'll worry about vacation travel, little kids will steel themselves to endure banging fireworks; older kids will cajole for extra tickets at carnivals.The national animal on that day will be the cow - revered source of hamburger. About ten days later the royal baby will be born.

There'll be swimming pools, beaches, and controversies about sunscreen. I grew up with suntan lotion. My annual entanglement with sunscreen now tends to be the song "Everybody's Free To Wear Sunscreen" with lyrics by Mary Schmich who wrote them in 1997 while a columnist for the Chicago Tribune.

Everybody's Free To Wear Sunscreen is up on YouTube. It's a refreshing balm in these days of media frenzy - well at least Republican frenzy.

And comes August, with its too soon back to school rituals, one of the more lame ideas introduced by school administrators to beat China in education. The most lame idea was doing away with recess. Lucky kids will have 4H projects and animals to enter at county fairs.

Finally will come Labor Day. it's a time to read FDR's September 6th, 1936 Labor Day speech and savor his magical optimism as he weaves labor, owners, and our common bonds together into a nation.

It is time to simplify the tax code!

This a a chance to overhaul the entire IRS to make it a user-friendly operation.

After all, USA taxpayers are like shareholders in the government. Taxpayers pay to run the IRS and pay all its employees' salaries and benefits.

The taxpayer deserves to know the guidelines and rules upfront. Taxpayers should be able to discuss their situations and qualifications with a knowledgeable representative (not ambiguous websites) BEFORE making applications or filing returns. Problems like this could have been avoided in the first place.

Audits are time-consuming and expensive for both the IRS and the taxpayer, especially during an economic crisis. It's so backwards. We need a system that respects all taxpayers and businesses and treats them like valued customers.

Lack of oversight and lack of common sense management has created an adversarial system. It doesn't have to be this way.

Nina Olson, the IRS taxpayer advocate, has been almost totally ignored.

It is time for President Obama to announce a new IRS mission to serve the taxpayer.
